faux leather.summary: Plastic-based alternative to leather. Less ethical concern, but not biodegradable.

cotton.summary: Natural and biodegradable, but water- and pesticide-intensive to grow conventionally.

stone.summary: Durable natural material with long lifespan. Mining causes habitat disruption and requires energy.

stoneware.summary: Durable ceramic material fired at high temperatures. Energy-intensive production but long-lasting.

wood.summary: Renewable, biodegradable natural material. Impact depends on forest management practices.

concrete.summary: Cement-based material with high carbon footprint from limestone calcination. Extremely durable.

brick.summary: Clay-based building material fired at high temperatures. Energy-intensive but extremely long-lasting.

steel.summary: Alloy with high embodied energy but indefinitely recyclable. Essential for infrastructure.

aluminum.summary: Lightweight metal with very high initial energy cost, but highly recyclable with lower energy for recycling.

cement.summary: Key ingredient in concrete responsible for 8% of global CO2 emissions. Extremely high impact.

glass.summary: Made from abundant materials but energy-intensive to produce. Infinitely recyclable without quality loss.

plastics.summary: Petroleum-based materials that persist in environment. Varies by type but generally problematic at end-of-life.

iron.summary: Base metal for steel. Energy-intensive to extract from ore but recyclable and abundant.

copper.summary: Excellent conductor with limited global supply. Mining has significant environmental impacts.

timber.summary: Processed wood product with carbon sequestration benefits. Renewable if sustainably harvested.

lead.summary: Toxic heavy metal with serious health concerns. Highly recyclable but requires careful handling.

brass.summary: Copper-zinc alloy with good durability. Uses less energy than pure copper but still resource-intensive.

acrylic.summary: Petroleum-based plastic with clarity and durability. Non-biodegradable and difficult to recycle.

ceramic.summary: Durable and non-toxic, but typically not recyclable and energy-intensive to fire.

lumber.summary: Processed wood with minimal processing. Renewable when sustainably harvested. Carbon-storing.

plywood.summary: Engineered wood with adhesives. More resource-efficient than solid wood but contains resins.

chipboard.summary: Made from wood waste and adhesives. Utilizes scraps but contains formaldehyde-based resins.

osb.summary: Engineered wood made from oriented strands with adhesives. Material-efficient but contains resins.

insulation.summary: Materials vary widely from natural fibers to petroleum-based foam. Impact depends on specific type.

roofing.summary: Materials range from petroleum-based shingles to metal or clay. Durability and impact varies by type.

siding.summary: Exterior cladding varies from vinyl to fiber cement. Environmental impact depends on material choice.

plaster.summary: Traditional wall finish made from gypsum, lime or cement. Moderate energy for production.

drywall.summary: Gypsum-based wallboard. Moderately energy-intensive but recyclable in specialized facilities.

carbon steel.summary: Iron alloy with carbon. High initial energy but durable and recyclable. Essential structural material.

low-alloy steel.summary: Steel with small amounts of other elements for improved properties. Similar impact to carbon steel.

tool steel.summary: High-carbon steel specialized for durability. Higher embodied energy but extremely long-lasting.

stainless steel.summary: Corrosion-resistant steel with chromium. Higher impact than carbon steel but very durable.

cast iron.summary: High-carbon iron alloy that's extremely durable. Recyclable and often contains recycled content.

nickel alloys.summary: Specialty metals for extreme environments. High embodied energy but very durable.

titanium alloys.summary: Lightweight, strong metal with very high extraction and processing energy requirements.

zinc.summary: Metal used in galvanizing and alloys. Mining has significant impacts but is recyclable.

tin.summary: Metal used in alloys and coatings. Limited global supply with significant mining impacts.

polyethylene.summary: Common plastic used in packaging. Petroleum-based, non-biodegradable but technically recyclable.

polypropylene.summary: Versatile plastic used in many products. Petroleum-based, non-biodegradable but recyclable.

pvc.summary: Produces toxic chlorine-based chemicals when burned. Often non-recyclable.

polystyrene.summary: Petroleum-based plastic used in foam packaging. Difficult to recycle and persists in environment.

polyurethane.summary: Versatile plastic used in foams and coatings. Non-biodegradable and difficult to recycle.

abs.summary: Plastic used in 3D printing and electronics. Non-biodegradable, recyclable in specialized systems.

pmma.summary: Clear acrylic plastic with good optical properties. Petroleum-based and non-biodegradable.

ptfe.summary: Non-stick fluoropolymer with extreme chemical resistance. Persistent in environment.

nylon.summary: Synthetic polymer used in textiles and engineering. Petroleum-based with high water usage.

epoxy.summary: Thermosetting polymer used in adhesives and coatings. Non-recyclable once cured.

silk.summary: Natural protein fiber from silkworms. Biodegradable but involves boiling silkworm cocoons.

linen.summary: Natural fiber made from flax. Biodegradable and strong, with moderate environmental footprint.

rayon.summary: Semi-synthetic fabric from cellulose. Biodegradable but chemically intensive to produce.

polyester.summary: Synthetic polymer fabric. Non-biodegradable, microfiber shedding issues, but recyclable.

wool.summary: Natural protein fiber from sheep. Biodegradable and renewable but has livestock impacts.

velvet.summary: Woven fabric with dense pile surface. Environmental impact depends on fiber composition.

chiffon.summary: Lightweight, sheer fabric. Impact depends on whether it's silk (natural) or synthetic.

georgette.summary: Lightweight crepe fabric. Environmental impact depends on fiber composition.

crepe.summary: Fabric with distinctive crinkled surface. Impact varies based on fiber source.

fleece.summary: Synthetic insulating fabric often made from recycled PET. Sheds microplastics when washed.

seersucker.summary: Cotton fabric with puckered texture. Impact depends on cotton growing practices.

tulle.summary: Lightweight, fine netting. Usually made from synthetic fibers with moderate impact.

denim.summary: Durable cotton twill fabric. Water-intensive production with high dye chemical usage.

jersey.summary: Stretchy knit fabric. Environmental impact depends on fiber composition.

flannel.summary: Soft woven fabric, typically cotton. Impact depends on growing and processing methods.

satin.summary: Smooth, glossy fabric with floating thread structure. Impact varies by fiber content.

corduroy.summary: Durable cotton fabric with distinctive ridges. Water-intensive production.

tapa cloth.summary: Traditional Polynesian barkcloth made from tree bark. Natural and biodegradable.

organza.summary: Thin, plain weave, sheer fabric traditionally made from silk. Now often synthetic.

jute.summary: Natural fiber from Corchorus plants. Biodegradable with minimal pesticide requirements.

hemp.summary: Fast-growing natural fiber requiring minimal pesticides. Highly sustainable and biodegradable.

canvas.summary: Heavy-duty woven fabric. Durable and biodegradable depending on the fiber source.

microfiber.summary: Synthetic fabric with very fine fibers. Sheds microplastics that pollute waterways.

rubber.summary: Natural or synthetic elastomer. Natural rubber is biodegradable, synthetic is petroleum-based.

leather.summary: Animal hide processed with tanning chemicals. Biodegradable but raises ethical concerns.

paper.summary: Wood pulp-based sheet material. Recyclable and biodegradable with moderate processing impact.

cardboard.summary: Recyclable and biodegradable. Often used in eco-friendly packaging.

cork.summary: Natural material harvested from cork oak bark. Renewable, biodegradable and carbon-negative.

wood pulp.summary: Processed wood fibers used in paper production. Impact depends on forest management.

graphite.summary: Crystalline form of carbon used in pencils and lubricants. Minimal processing impact.

diamond.summary: Natural diamonds have significant mining impacts. Lab-grown alternatives reduce impact.

ceramics.summary: Clay-based materials fired at high temperatures. Energy-intensive but durable and inert.

metal.summary: Category including various metals. Most require significant energy to produce but are recyclable.

tanning agents.summary: Chemicals used to process leather. Often contain chromium and other toxic compounds.

dyeing agents.summary: Chemicals used to color textiles. Can contain heavy metals and cause water pollution.

glues.summary: Adhesives varying from natural to synthetic. Petroleum-based types often contain VOCs.

adhesives.summary: Bonding compounds that vary widely. Many contain volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

paint.summary: Surface coating with pigments and binders. Oil-based types contain more harmful compounds.

paints.summary: Surface coatings with varying environmental impacts. Water-based have lower toxicity.

water-based paint.summary: Paint using water as solvent rather than petroleum-based solvents. Lower VOC emissions.

bamboo.summary: Fast-growing grass with excellent renewability. Minimal pesticide requirements and carbon sequestration.

rattan.summary: Palm-based natural material used in furniture. Renewable and biodegradable.

coir.summary: Natural fiber from coconut husks. Biodegradable with minimal processing requirements.

sisal.summary: Natural fiber from agave plants. Drought-resistant crop with minimal pesticide needs.

kapok.summary: Silky fiber from kapok tree seed pods. Natural, renewable, and biodegradable insulation material.

down.summary: Insulating feathers from waterfowl. Biodegradable but raises animal welfare concerns.

lyocell.summary: Semi-synthetic cellulosic fiber produced in closed-loop process. Low chemical and water usage.

modal.summary: Semi-synthetic cellulosic fiber. More eco-friendly processing than rayon but still resource-intensive.

acetate.summary: Semi-synthetic fiber made from cellulose. Biodegradable but requires chemical processing.

viscose.summary: Semi-synthetic cellulosic fiber. Can have high chemical and water usage in production.

spandex.summary: Synthetic elastomeric fiber. Non-biodegradable with petroleum-based inputs.

elastane.summary: Synthetic stretch fiber similar to spandex. Petroleum-based and non-biodegradable.

cashmere.summary: Ultra-fine natural wool from cashmere goats. Biodegradable but resource-intensive.

mohair.summary: Natural wool from angora goats. Biodegradable but raises animal welfare concerns.

alpaca.summary: Natural wool with lower environmental impact than sheep wool. Biodegradable.

merino wool.summary: Fine natural wool from merino sheep. High-quality renewable fiber but involves livestock.

fiberglass.summary: Glass fiber composite. Non-biodegradable but energy-efficient as insulation.

carbon fiber.summary: High-strength composite material. Very energy-intensive production process.

kevlar.summary: Aramid fiber with high strength. Energy-intensive production but extremely durable.

bioplastic.summary: Plastic derived from renewable biomass. Biodegradable varieties available but not universal.

pla.summary: Biodegradable thermoplastic from renewable resources like corn starch. Compostable in industrial facilities.

pbat.summary: Biodegradable plastic blend used in compostable bags. Petroleum-derived but biodegradable.

pha.summary: Naturally occurring biopolymer produced by bacteria. Fully biodegradable in various environments.

recycled polyester.summary: Made from post-consumer plastic bottles. Lower energy than virgin polyester but still sheds microplastics.

econyl.summary: Regenerated nylon made from fishing nets and carpet. Reduces waste but still synthetic.

recycled cotton.summary: Made from post-industrial or post-consumer cotton waste. Reduces water and chemical usage.

reclaimed wood.summary: Wood salvaged from old structures. Minimal processing energy and prevents waste.

terracotta.summary: Unglazed, porous clay material. Lower firing temperature than many ceramics.

porcelain.summary: High-fired ceramic with higher energy requirements but exceptional durability.

marble.summary: Natural stone requiring quarrying and cutting. Energy-intensive extraction but extremely durable.

granite.summary: Hard natural stone requiring quarrying. High extraction energy but extremely long-lasting.

limestone.summary: Sedimentary rock used in construction and cement. Quarrying impacts but naturally abundant.

sandstone.summary: Natural sedimentary stone used in construction. Quarrying impacts but naturally abundant.

slate.summary: Fine-grained metamorphic rock used for roofing and flooring. Durable with long lifespan.

quartz.summary: Engineered stone combining crushed quartz with resins. Durable but contains non-biodegradable components.

terrazzo.summary: Composite material with marble chips in cement. Durable and often uses recycled content.

linoleum.summary: Natural flooring made from linseed oil, cork and wood flour. Biodegradable alternative to vinyl.

vinyl.summary: PVC-based synthetic flooring and wall covering. Contains phthalates and non-biodegradable.

mdf.summary: Medium-density fiberboard made from wood fibers and resin. Contains formaldehyde-based adhesives.

oriented strand board.summary: Engineered wood made from oriented wood strands. Utilizes wood waste but contains adhesives.

coconut fiber.summary: Natural fiber from coconut husks. Biodegradable and uses agricultural byproduct.

abaca.summary: Natural fiber from banana plant species. Strong, water-resistant, and biodegradable.

ramie.summary: Natural plant fiber similar to flax. Biodegradable with minimal pesticide requirements.

lyocell tencel.summary: Sustainable cellulosic fiber produced in closed-loop system with minimal chemicals and water.

piñatex.summary: Leather alternative made from pineapple leaf fibers. Uses agricultural waste and biodegradable.

mushroom leather.summary: Leather alternative grown from mycelium. Biodegradable and requires minimal resources.

mycelium.summary: Fungal-based material used for packaging and leather alternatives. Biodegradable and low-impact.

seacell.summary: Cellulosic fiber containing seaweed. Biodegradable with beneficial skin properties.

milk fiber.summary: Protein fiber made from casein in milk. Biodegradable but requires chemical processing.

soy fabric.summary: Protein fiber made from soy byproducts. Biodegradable but requires chemical processing.

qmonos.summary: Lab-created artificial spider silk. High-performance biodegradable fiber with minimal resources.

s.cafe.summary: Fabric made from recycled coffee grounds. Utilizes waste and has natural odor control.

orange fiber.summary: Cellulosic fabric made from citrus juice byproducts. Uses agricultural waste.

bananatex.summary: Fabric made from banana plant fibers. Biodegradable and uses minimal chemicals.

recycled nylon.summary: Made from post-consumer and industrial nylon waste. Reduces petroleum use and waste.

recycled wool.summary: Made from post-consumer and industrial wool waste. Reduces water and dye usage.

reclaimed rubber.summary: Made from recycled tires and rubber products. Prevents waste but still not biodegradable.

recovered plastic.summary: Plastic retrieved from oceans and waterways. Prevents environmental damage but still synthetic.

nettle fiber.summary: Natural fiber similar to linen. Requires minimal pesticides and grows on marginal land.

rose fiber.summary: Cellulosic fiber made from rose bush byproducts. Utilizes waste from oil production.

lotus fiber.summary: Rare natural fiber extracted from lotus stems. Labor-intensive but chemical-free process.

recycled leather.summary: Made from leather scraps and shavings bonded together. Reduces waste but contains adhesives.

apple leather.summary: Vegan leather alternative made from apple industry waste. Biodegradable and uses byproducts.

grape leather.summary: Leather alternative made from grape waste from wine industry. Utilizes agricultural byproducts.

cactus leather.summary: Leather alternative made from nopal cactus. Requires minimal water and no irrigation.

palm leather.summary: Leather alternative made from palm leaves. Biodegradable and uses renewable resources.

sanding dust.summary: Wood byproduct that can be used in fiberboard. Utilizes waste from wood processing.

rice hulls.summary: Agricultural byproduct used in packaging. Biodegradable and abundantly available.

sunflower hulls.summary: Agricultural byproduct used in composite materials. Biodegradable fiber source.

wheat straw.summary: Agricultural byproduct used in paper and building materials. Uses waste from food production.

bagasse.summary: Sugarcane fiber byproduct used in paper and packaging. Biodegradable with minimal processing.
